description.narrative: The overall aim of the proposed development intervention is that “Women are empowered to lead, participate in, influence and contribute to national development.”To achieve this aim, the development intervention defines six result areas: 1) Women lead and participate in decision making at all levels. 2) Women, especially the poorest and most excluded, are economically empowered and benefit from development. 3) Women and girls live a life free from violence. 4) Peace and security and humanitarian action are shaped by women leadership and participation. 5) Governance and national planning fully reflect accountability for gender equality commitments and priorities. 6) Normative and policy framework for gender equality and women's empowerment strengthened and implemented.

The Government of Uganda has made significant progress in developing legal frameworks, policies and programmes which respect, protect and promote human rights and empowerment of women and girls. Progress, however, often remains at the policy level with implementation on the ground lacking behind due to inadequate capacity or priority in government institutions.
As a result, women in Uganda continue to be marginalized and experience discrimination in in all spheres of life.
Women’s political participation and representation has progressed with women in Parliament increasing from 18% in 2000 to 35% in 2012; mainly owing to the Affirmative Action Policy. Women have also gained ground in Cabinet and Local Councils, yet party leadership and structures remain heavily male-dominated and patriarchal. Higher illiteracy and poverty levels among women compared to men mean that women are unable to compete on a level playing field in the highly monetized electoral process.
Women’s Economic Empowerment (WEE) constitutes another major obstacle to gender equality as well as to more overall development goals. Women have poor access to reproductive resources, and especially access to land and land tenure are areas of discrimination. Consequently, women struggle to access financial services including loans due to lack of collateral. Although 76% of Ugandan women are active in the labor market, women tend to concentrate in feminized occupations, clustering in low-value chains, part-time or informal employment.
Violence against women and girls (VAWG) remains another main obstacle to the empowerment of women with the prevalence and social acceptance of VAWG consistently high. In addition, the link between WEE and VAWG is becoming increasingly apparent in Uganda. A great part of the violence reported at household level is economically motivated, with peaks around harvest periods.
Finally, gender mainstreaming in peace building and humanitarian action is inadequate and often poorly coordinated. At the local level, heightened conflict over land in the Acholi region is exacerbated by discovery of oil in the Albertine region, and at the regional level, long-lasting conflicts in neighboring countries cause a continuing refugee influx to the northern and western parts of Uganda. Insecurity and humanitarian situations affect women and girls disproportionally, yet an effective coordination of gender issues in the security and humanitarian response is yet to be established.
In response to the above situation analysis, the development intervention will provide core support to UN Women Uganda to implement the first three years (2016-2018) of its Strategic Note 2016-2020 with a total contribution of 66.5 M SEK (22 % of the total 5 year Strategic Note budget, 36% of the budget for the three years covered by the Agreement).
UN Women established its country office in Uganda in 2010 (with a head office in Kampala and with district offices in Gulu and Moroto), and during her time of operation in the country, UN Women has positioned herself as a key actor for gender equality and women’s empowerment. With the support from Sweden, UN Women will be able to roll out a comprehensive country program which is expected to have a significant catalytic effect on gender issues in the country.
In 2018, Sweden plans to initiate a dialogue with UN Women about the possibility to extend the support to cover the remaining two years of the 2016-2020 Strategic Note, depending on the experiences and results achieved during the first three years of support.
UN Women Uganda developed its Strategic Note 2016-2020 through an inclusive and consultative process ensuring high levels of stakeholder buy-in and increasing sustainability. The overall goal of the Strategic Note is to empower women to lead, participate in, influence and contribute to national development in Uganda.
In line with UN Women’s Global Strategic Plan, the development intervention targets six programmatic result areas: 1) Women lead and participate in decision making at all levels; 2) Women, especially the poorest and most excluded, are economically empowered and benefit from development, 3) Women and girls live a life free from violence, 4) Peace and security and humanitarian action are shaped by women’s leadership and participation, 5) Governance and national planning fully reflect accountability for gender equality commitments and priorities, and 6) Global normative and policy framework for gender equality and women’s empowerment strengthened and implemented. In addition, the development intervention has a seventh result area on organizational effectiveness and efficiency.
Together, the six programmatic result areas address two fundamental and underlying root causes behind the marginalization of women in Uganda: The deep rooted cultural and traditional practices discriminating against women and girls across all levels and spheres of life, and the fact that while Uganda has made strides in enacting laws that respect, protect and promote gender equality and women’s empowerment, national capacities for implementation is inadequate.
UN Women will work through partners to implement the intervention at both national and district level. National level interventions will leverage the normative work of UN Women and UN Women’s role as a broker to facilitate policy and institutional reform. District level interventions will focus on empowerment of women and girls in 11 selected districts: Gulu, Pader, Kitgum, Agago, Lamwo, Adjumani, Moroto, Kaabong, Kotido, Kamuli and Kaberamaido. The districts are selected under the 2016-2020 UN Development Assistance Framework (UNDAF) due to a) consistently lagging behind key development indicators (Karamoja region), post-conflict focus (Northern Uganda), c) highest national domestic violence prevalence (Eastern Uganda) and refugee influx from South Sudan (Adjumani area).
The focus helps to ensure that the development intervention will compliment other contributions under the Embassy’s 2014-2018 Results Strategy, including the contribution to Diakonia which has a strong down-stream focus on prevention of sexual and gender based violence through women’s economic empowerment, and the planned contribution to aBi Trust with strong linkages to women’s economic empowerment.
Globally, UN Women is a strategic partner for Sweden in realizing Swedish commitments on gender equality and women’s empowerment, and UN Women’s mandate is fully aligned with Swedish development priorities.
UN Women is a new organization with high potentials, and it is a priority for Sweden to actively engage with UN Women, both at HQ and at country level. UN Women needs strategic partnerships, and Sweden is committed to support UN Women with its positioning as a strong political and strategic player in the gender landscape to fully maximize its leverage for better results on the ground.
In the Ugandan context; UN Women Uganda is in a strategic position vis-à-vis its mandate, partnerships and experiences, to contribute to the realization of Sweden’s 2014-2018 Result Strategy for the country.
Sweden is the largest donor to UN Women globally, and with a view to the financial challenges UN Women is facing at country level, Sweden is positive to provide core support to UN Women at this level.

Uganda har gjort betydande framsteg vad gäller lagstiftning och policyarbetet på nationell nivå för att stärka, skydda och främja de mänskliga rättigheterna samt kvinnors och flickors egenmakt. Framstegen håller sig dock fortfarande på politisk nivå och ofta saknas kapacitet att genomföra arbetet på lokal nivå och det prioriteras inte heller av de statliga institutionerna. Kvinnor i är således fortsatt marginaliserade i Uganda och diskrimineras på de flesta områden i samhället.
Kvinnors politiska deltagande och representation har förbättrats. Andelen kvinnor i parlamentet har ökat från 18% år 2000 till 35% år 2012; främst som ett resultat av kvotering. Kvinnor har också tagit plats i beslutande organ både på nationell och distriktsnvå, men ledningsstrukturerna är fortsatt starkt mansdominerade och patriarkala. Analfabetism och fattigdom är mer utbrett bland kvinnor än män vilket leder till att kvinnor inte kan konkurrera på lika villkor.
Kvinnors ekonomiska egenmakt (WEE) utgör ytterligare ett stort hinder för såväl jämställdheten som de mer övergripande utvecklingsmålen i Uganda. Kvinnor har sämre tillgång till produktiva resurser; till exempel tillgång till mark är ett områden där kvinnor diskrimineras. Kvinnor har också sämre tillgång till finansiella tjänster, inklusive lån eftersom de ofta saknar säkerhet. Trots att 76% av ugandiska kvinnor är aktiva på arbetsmarknaden, tenderar kvinnor att hänvisas till traditionella kvinnoyrken, deltidsarbete eller informell sysselsättning.
Våld mot kvinnor och flickor (VAWG) är ytterligare ett stort hinder för kvinnors egenmakt och Uganda har genomgående hög prevalens och social acceptans vad gäller detta. Dessutom blir kopplingen mellan WEE och VAWG allt tydligare i Uganda. En stor del av våldet sker inom hushållen och är ofta ekonomiskt motiverad, med toppar kring skördeperioder.
Jämställdhetsintegrering i fredsbyggande och humanitära insatser är otillräcklig och ofta dåligt samordnad. På lokal nivå har landkonflikterna i Acholi regionen förvärrats som en konsekvens av oljefyndigheterna som gjorts relativt nyligen. De långvariga konflikterna i grannländerna orsakar en fortsatt tillströmningen av flyktingar till de norra och västra delarna av Uganda. Otryggheten och den humanitära situationer påverkar kvinnor och flickor hårdare är genomsnittet. En effektiv samordning av jämställdhetsfrågor i humanitära insatser finns ännu inte på plats.
Den föreslagna insatsen kommer att svara mot situationen som beskrivs ovan genom ett grundläggande stöd till UN Women Uganda för att genomföra de första tre åren (2016-2018) av sin strategiska plan 2016-2020 med ett totalt finansiellt bidrag på 66,5 miljoner kronor (22% av den totalt 5-årig strategiska plannen budget, 36% av budgeten för de tre år som omfattas av avtalet).
UN Women etablerade sitt landkontor i Uganda 2010 (med huvudkontor i Kampala och distriktskontor i Gulu och Moroto), och har sedan dess positionerat sig som en viktig aktör för jämställdhet och kvinnors egenmakt. Med stöd från Sverige kommer UN Women kunna rulla ut en omfattande landprogram som förväntas ha en betydande katalytisk effekt på hur jämställdhetsfrågorna drivs i landet.
År 2018 planerar ambassaden att inleda en dialog med UN Women om möjligheten att utvidga stöd för att täcka de återstående två åren av den strategiska planen 2016-2020. En sådan dialog kommer att vara baserad på erfarenheter och resultat som uppnåtts under de första tre åren.
UN Women Uganda har utvecklat sin strategiska plan 2016-2020 med aktivt deltagande av sina partners och andra intressenter vilket borgar för hållbarhet i programmet. Det övergripande målet för den strategiska planen är att stärka kvinnors ställning för att leda, delta i och påverka den nationella utvecklingen i Uganda.
I linje med UN Womens globala strategiska plan, fokuserar insatsen på sex resultatområden: 1) Women lead and participate in decision making at all levels; 2) Women, especially the poorest and most excluded, are economically empowered and benefit from development, 3) Women and girls live a life free from violence, 4) Peace and security and humanitarian action are shaped by women’s leadership and participation, 5) Governance and national planning fully reflect accountability for gender equality commitments and priorities, and 6) Global normative and policy framework for gender equality and women’s empowerment strengthened and implemented. Insatsen har också ett sjunde resultatområde som handlar om effektivitet och ändamålsenlighet av programmet.
Tillsammans bidrar de sex programresultatområden till att addressera två fundamentala och underliggande orsaker till marginaliseringen av kvinnor i Uganda: De djupt rotade kulturella och traditionella sedvänjor som diskriminerar kvinnor och flickor på alla nivåer och områden i livet, och det faktum att kapacitet saknas för att genomföra lagar policyer.
UN Women kommer att arbeta via partners i genomförandet av insatsen på både nationell och distriktsnivå. På nationell nivå kommer insatsen att dra nytta av UN Womens normativa arbete och deras roll som mäklare för att underlätta politiska och institutionella reformer. På distriktsnivå kommer insatsen att fokusera på kvinnors och flickors egenmakt i 11 utvalda distrikt: Gulu, Pader, Kitgum, Agago, Lamwo, Adjumani, Moroto, Kaabong, Kotido, Kamuli och Kaberamaido. Distrikten väljs ut inom ramen för 2016-2020 UN Development Assistance Framework (UNDAF) med följande kriterier a) backlog när det gäller jämställdhetsindikatorer (Karamoja region), postkonfliktfokus (norra Uganda), c) landets högsta prevalens av våld mot kvinnor och flickor (östra Uganda ) och tillströmningen av flyktingar från södra Sudan (Adjumani området).
Insatsens fokus kompletterar andra insatser som genomförs inom ramen för den svenska strategin för Uganda 2014-2018, till exemple stödet till Diakonia, som fokuserar på förebyggande av sexuellt och könsrelaterat våld genom kvinnors ekonomiska egenmakt och ambassadens planerade stöd till aBi Trust som har starka kopplingar till kvinnors ekonomiska egenmakt.
Globalt sett är UN Women en strategisk partner för Sverige att förverkliga svenska åtaganden om jämställdhet och kvinnors egenmakt, och UN Womens mandat ligger helt i linje med svenska utvecklingsprioriteringar.
I den ugandiska kontexten; har UN Women genom sitt mandat en strategisk position att bidra till förverkligandet av Sveriges 2014-2018 Resultat strategi för landet. UN Women är en relativt ny organisation med stor potential, och också en strategisk partner för Sverige såväl centralt som på landnivå.
Sverige är den största bidragsgivaren till UN Women globalt, och med tanke på de ekonomiska utmaningar UN Women står inför på nationell nivå och resonemanget ovan, ställer sig Sverige positivt till att ge kärnstöd till UN Women i Uganda.

description.narrative:
Since Sweden is funding UN Women with core support, there are many results to report on. The programme is quite comprehensive and results can be found on many different levels. The latest report submitted 28 June 2019 is quite detailed and results can be found there. Some of the highlights mentioned are: Some of the result highlights mentioned in the report: - Comprehensive support to women candidates to run for political offices during the local council elections 2018 leading to 148 newly elected women leaders. - Massive civic education, reaching over 4,2 million Ugandans, on women in politics and leadership contributed to change negative social/cultural perceptions of women as leaders. - In total over 13 million people have been reached with messages in media and social media on respectful relationships, non-violent dispute resolution and gender equality and ending violence against women and girls. Actual change in the level of awareness on VAWG and changes in attitudes and behaviors will be measured in 2020 at the end of UN Women’s Country Strategic note. It is however noted that, at national level, there was a 9.2% decrease in reported cases of domestic violence to the Police from 15,325 cases in 2017 to 13,916 cases in 2018. - Important legislation was put forward to parliament on inheritance, land and property issues. - Several hundred women entrepreneurs aquired skilles to make their business profitable, which also has led to them being able to secure their childrens education needs. - The Uganda Police Force completed and launched its Gender Policy and Strategy which provides a framework for gender mainstreaming and promotion of respect for the rights and dignity of women, men, boys and girls seeking services of, or working in the police force. - Over 20,000 people have received legal aid services, including legal representation in court, mainly on land or violence. - Over 200,000 people have received information on GBV services and how to access them. - Comprehensive support to over 8,000 refugees for psycho-social support. Information on GBV in refugee receiving aras has resulted in over 5,000 indivudials reporting cases of SGBV. - On engaging men and boys; UN Women’s partners ( UPF, SafeBoda, Greater North Parliamentary Forum and Wangoo Forum) conducted dedicated activities using the HeForShe campaign to engage men and boys in EVAW. - Compilation and reporting of the SDGs was institutionalized with UN Women technical and financial support to UBOS and the Prime Minister’s Office (OPM). There is increased harmonization of national development indicators and the SDG targets across the 17 SDGs. - On Gender Responsive Budgeting, UN women provided technical and financial support to the EOC to develop a National Inventory which tracks gender equality commitments from Ministerial Policy Gender statements. The Inventory will be used in 2019 to monitor financial allocations made on gender issues per sector.
On coordination, UN Women has stepped up considerably. They recognize the importance of the agency as technical support to larger agencies, leveraging results on gender equality on a much broader scale. They state that they will pursue this mission even more 2029 and 2020 and make sure to document their achievements and impact better. It is interesting to note that the analytical quality of UN Women seems to improve. Thanks to better follow up, they are increasingly good at presenting lessons learnt (also in a more transparent way) and challenges. I think it could be considered a result of our dialogue that they for example state that it has paid off to adopt a human rights approach across programme implementation. Rights holders in every sector (beneficiaries) were identified and their capacity strengthened to understand, influence, monitor and benefit from public policies and programmes. This allowed them to see beyond their immediate needs and perceive their role in public accountability. At the same time duty bearers were also supported to ensure availability and quality of public services, and to facilitate the exercise of citizens’ monitoring rights. UN Women states that they will systematize this approach in the coming years and its impact measured more accurately. One important result is also that UN Women to a larger extent established bridges between the different areas of intervention. As they write: "VAW issues were addressed in our WEE programmes, and Governance and leadership issues were integrated in our women peace and security activities. On top of the cross-fertilization that this approach allowed us to achieve, we also gained in effectiveness as some tools (e.g. leadership, human rights, logistics, etc.) were used across the board." This might seem basic, but still an important observation to make sure results are enhanced over time.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
